intro: Ranunculus guzmannii, commonly known as the Guzmán's buttercup, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly found in regions of Argentina and Chile. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family, which includes many showy, often toxic plants. The plant features delicate, palmate leaves and brightly colored, typically yellow or orange flowers with numerous petals. It thrives in moist, temperate climates and is often found in mountainous or forested areas. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
